2.text: Hear, I beseech you, my words, and do penance.

3.text: Suffer me, and I will speak, and after, if you please, laugh at my words.

4.text: Is my debate against man, that I should not have just reason to be troubled?

5.text: Hearken to me and be astonished, and lay your finger on your mouth.

6.text: As for me, when I remember, I am afraid, and trembling taketh hold on my flesh.

7.text: Why then do the wicked live, are they advanced, and strengthened with riches?

8.text: Their seed continueth before them, a multitude of kinsmen, and of childrenâ€™s children in their sight.

9.text: Their houses are secure and peaceable, and the rod of God is not upon them.

10.text: Their cattle have conceived, and failed not: their cow has calved, and is not deprived of her fruit.

11.text: Their little ones go out like a flock, and their children dance and play.

12.text: They take the timbrel, and the harp, and rejoice at the sound of the organ.

13.text: They spend their days in wealth, and in a moment they go down to hell.

14.text: Who have said to God: Depart from us, we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.

15.text: Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him? and what doth it profit us if we pray to him?

16.text: Yet because their good things are not in their hand, may the counsel of the wicked be far from me.

17.text: How often shall the lamp of the wicked be put out, and a deluge come upon them, and he shall distribute the sorrows of his wrath?

18.text: They shall be as chaff before the face of the wind, and as ashes which the whirlwind scattereth.

19.text: God shall lay up the sorrow of the father for his children: and when he shall repay, then shall he know.

20.text: His eyes shall see his own destruction, and he shall drink of the wrath of the Almighty.

21.text: For what is it to him what befalleth his house after him: and if the number of his months be diminished by one half?

22.text: Shall any one teach God knowledge, who judgeth those that are high?

23.text: One man dieth strong, and hale, rich and happy.

24.text: His bowels are full of fat, and his bones are moistened with marrow.

25.text: But another dieth in bitterness of soul without any riches:

26.text: And yet they shall sleep together in the dust, and worms shall cover them.

27.text: Surely I know your thoughts, and your unjust judgments against me.

28.text: For you say: Where is the house of the prince ? and where are the dwelling places of the wicked?

29.text: Ask any one of them that go by the way, and you shall perceive that he knoweth these same things.

30.text: Because the wicked man is reserved to the day of destruction, and he shall be brought to the day of wrath.

31.text: Who shall reprove his way to his face? and who shall repay him what he hath done?

32.text: He shall be brought to the graves, and shall watch in the heap of the dead.

33.text: He hath been acceptable to the gravel of Cocytus, and he shall draw every man after him, and there are innumerable before him.

34.text: How then do ye comfort me in vain, whereas your answer is shewn to be repugnant to truth ?
